I simply cannot recommend trusting it

to how on OLED each pixel emits its own
light well the thing is there isn't
enough power available to drive all of
the pixels at once at their highest
brightness which is where average pixel
levels or APL comes in so in order to
achieve high levels of brightness in
some spots on the display saturation and
therefore color accuracy has to be
sacrificed to make sure that the display
as a whole doesn't consume more than its
overall power budget the most obvious
situation where this can be seen is that
the color accuracy of the panel goes up
by 35% just by going from the brightest
setting to one notch down now this might
seem like a crazy design decision but
for watching videos or playing video
games this is a trade-off that I agree
is well worth it because our eyes are
much more sensitive to changes in
brightness than they are to changes in
color it just also means that as I said
unfortunately this panel can't be
trusted by digital artists because if
they were to go and change their
brightness their accuracy could all of a
sudden be way off and we haven't even
mentioned the elephant in the room
burnin with OLED since each individual
pixel is emitting its own light they can
actually degrade at different rates
depending on what kind of light they're
used to emitting throughout their
lifetime so if there's an area of your
screen that's always bright like say the
Start menu icon in Windows or the hot
outline of your favorite game after a
while
it could become edged into the panel
